sample_sentences: In her pursuit of an Olympic gold meda, the runner was fettered by multiple injuries.

definition: faithfulness; loyalty
sample_sentences: The motto of the United States Marine Corps is semper fidelis, which is Latin for always loyal.

definition: based on figures of speech; expressing something in terms usually used for something else; metaphorical
sample_sentences: "When the mayor said that the housing market had sprouted wings, she was speaking figuratively. The housing market hadnt really sprouted wings; it had merely risen so rapidly that it had almost seemed to fly."

definition: skillful maneuvering; subtlety; craftiness
sample_sentences: The doctor sewed up the wound with finesse, making stitches so small one could scarcely see them.

definition: glaringly bad; notorious; scandalous
to show off; to display ostentatiously
sample_sentences: The brand-new millionaire annoyed all his friends by driving around his old neighborhood to flaunt his new Rolls-Royce.

definition: to disregards something out of disrespect
sample_sentences: A driver flouts the traffic laws by driving  through red lights and knocking down pedestrains.

definition: a minor character flaw
sample_sentences: Patti's foibles included a tendency to prefer dogs to people.

definition: to stir up; to instigate
sample_sentences: The bad news from abroad fomented pessimism among professional investors.

definition: to refrain from; to abstain
sample_sentences: Stephen told me I could become a millionaire if i joined him in his business, but his lack of integrity makes me nervous so I decided no forbear.

definition: to do without; to forbear
sample_sentences: We had some of the chocolate cake, some of the chocolate mousse, and some of the chocolate cream pie. But we were worried about our weight, so we decided to forego the chocolate-covered potato chips. That is, we forewent them.

definition: to abandon; to renounce; to relinquish
sample_sentences: We urged Buddy to forsake his life with the alien beings and return to his job at the drugstore.

definition: accidental; occurring by chance
sample_sentences: The program's outcome was not the result of any plan but was entirely fortuitous.

definition: to fail; to collapse; to sink
sample_sentences: The candidate's campaign for the presidency foundered when it was revealed that she had once been married to a drug addict.

definition: like brothers
sample_sentences: The fraternal feelings of the group were strengthened by monthly fishing trips.

definition: frantic; frenzied
sample_sentences: There was a lot of frenetic activity in the office, but nothing ever seemed to get accomplished.

definition: economical; penny-pinching
sample_sentences: Laura was so frugal that she even tried to bargain with the checkout girl at the discount store.

definition: secretive; sly
sample_sentences: Cal wiggled his ears while the countess was talking to him in a furtive attemp to catch our attention.

definition: useless; hopeless
sample_sentences: A D+ average and no extracurricular interests to speak of meant that applying to Harvard was futile, but Lucinda hoped against hope.

definition: talktative; chatty
sample_sentences: Gabriella is gregarious and garroulous; she loves to hang out with the gang and gab.

definition: unskillful; awkward; maladroit
sample_sentences: Smadar had a poor sense of comic timing, and her gauche attempts to mock her left-handed friends soon left her with none.

definition: a type or category, especially of art or writing
sample_sentences: Daoyen displayed a great talent for a particular genre; the bawdy limerick.

definition: refined; polite; aristocratic; affecting refinement
sample_sentences: The ladies at the ball were too genteel to accept our invitation to the wrestling match.

definition: to make gestures, especially when speaking or in place of speaking
sample_sentences: Massimo gesticulated widely on the other side of the theater in an attempt to get our attention.

definition: surplus; an overabundance
sample_sentences: The internation oil shortage turned into an international oil glut with surprising speed.

definition: pompous; using a lot of big, fancy words in an attempt to sound impressive
sample_sentences: The new minister's grandiloquence got him in trouble with deacons, who wanted him to be more restrained in his sermons.

definition: absurdly exaggerated
sample_sentences: The scientist's grandious plan was to build a huge shopping center on the surface of the moon.

definition: given freely (said of something bad); unjustified; unprovoked; uncalled for
sample_sentences: The scathing review of the movie contained several gratuitous remarks about the love life of the director

definition: seriousness
sample_sentences: The newsanchor's nervous giggling was entirely inappropriate, given the gravity of the situation.

definition: sociable; enjoying the company of others
sample_sentences: Dirk was too gregarious to enjoy the fifteen years he spent in solitary confinement.

definition: cunning; duplicity; artfulness
sample_sentences: Stuart was shocked by the guile of the automobile mechanic, who had poked a hole in his radiator and then told him that it had sprung a leak.

definition: overused; trite; stale
sample_sentences: Michael's book was full of cliches and hackneyed phrases.

definition: unlucky
sample_sentences: Joe's hapless search for fun led him from one disappointment to another.

definition: a forerunner; a signal of
sample_sentences: A cloud of bad breath and body odor, which preceded him by several yeards everywhere he went, was Harold's harbinger.

definition: the pursuit of pleasure as a way of life
sample_sentences: A hedonist practices hedonism twenty-four hours a day.

definition: leadership, especially of one nation over another
sample_sentences: America once held an unchallenged nuclear hegemony.

definition: any belief that is strongly opposed to established beliefs
sample_sentences: Galileo was tried for the heresy of suggesting that the sun did not revolve around Earth. He was almost convinced of being a heretic, but he recanted his heretical view.

definition: impervious to external influence; airtight
sample_sentences: The president led a hermetic existence in the White House, as her advisers attempted to seal her off from the outside world.

definition: golden age; prime
sample_sentences: The heday of the British Navy ended a long, long time ago.

definition: a break or interruption, often from work
sample_sentences: Spencer looked forward to spring break as a welcome hiatus from the rigors of campus parties.

definition: an organization based on rank or degree; pecking order
sample_sentences: Kendra was very low in the State Department hierarchy. In fact, her phone number wasn't even listed in the State Department directory.

definition: overly dramatic; theatrical
sample_sentences: The chairman's histrionic presentation persuaded no one.

definition: sermon
sample_sentences: The football coach often began practice with a lengthy homily on the vitues of clean living.

definition: uniform; made entirely of one thing
sample_sentences: The kindergarten class was extremely homogeneous: all the children had blond hair and blue eyes.

definition: thrifty management of resources; livestock farming
sample_sentences: Husbandry is the practive of conserving money or resources. To husband is to economize. Everyone husbanded oil and electricity during the energy crisis of the 1970s.

definition: an exaggeration used as a figure of speech; exaggeration
sample_sentences: The candidate was guilty of hyperbole; all the facts in her speech were exaggerated.

definition: uncertain; unproven
sample_sentences: There were several hypothetical explanations for the strange phenomenon, but no one could say for certain what had caused it.

definition: one who attacks popular beliefs or institutions
sample_sentences: The popular columnist was an inveterate iconoclast, avidly attaching public figures no matter what their party affiliations.

definition: a system of social or political ideas
sample_sentences: The candidate never managed to communicate his ideology to the voters, so few people were able to grasp what he stood for.

definition: a peculiarity; an eccentricity
sample_sentences: Eating green beans drenched in ketchup for breakfast was one of Jordan's idiosyncrasies.

definition: charming in a rustic way; naturally peaceful
sample_sentences: They built their house on an idyllic spot. There was a babbling brook in back and unbroken view of wooded hills in front.

definition: deep disgrace
sample_sentences: The ignominy of losing the spelling bee was too much for Arnold, who decided to give up spelling altogether.

definition: illegal; not permitted
sample_sentences: Criminals engage in illicit activities.

definition: to move permanently to a new country
sample_sentences: Edwin immigrated to Canada, thinking the move would give his two-year-old daughter a better shot at attending the University of Toronto preschool.

definition: just about to happen
sample_sentences: The pink glow in the east made it clear that sunrise was imminent.

definition: unchangeable
sample_sentences: Jerry's mother had only one immutable rule: no dancing on the dinner table.

definition: fair; not favoring one side or the other; unbiased
sample_sentences: Jurors are supposed to be impartial rather than partial; they aren't supposed to make up their mind until they've heard all the evidence.

definition: flawless; entiely without sin
sample_sentences: The children's behavior was impeccable; they didn't pour dye into the swimming pool.

definition: like an emperor or an empire
sample_sentences: The palace was decorated with imperial splendor.

definition: not allowing anything to pass through; impenetrable
sample_sentences: A raincoat, if it is any good, is impervious to water. It is mad eof an impervious material.

definition: impulsive; extremely impatient
sample_sentences: Samantha was so impetuous that she never took more than a few seconds to make up her mind.

definition: to carry out
sample_sentences: Leo developed a plan for shortening the grass in his yard, but he was unable to implement it because he didn't have a lawn mower.

definition: powerless; helpless; unable to perform
sample_sentences: We felt impotent in the face of their overpowering opposition to our plan.

definition: to attack, especially to attack the truth or integrity of something
sample_sentences: The critic impugned the originality of Jacob's novel, claiming that long stretches of it had been lifted from the work of someone else.

definition: silly; senseless
sample_sentences: Their plan to make an indoor swimming pool by flooding their basement was inane.

definition: to begin officially; to induct formally into office
sample_sentences: The mayor inaugurated the new no-smoking policy and then celebrated by lighting up a big cigar.

definition: brilliant; giving off heat or light
sample_sentences: An incandescent person is one who gives off light or energy in a figurative sense.

definition: a chant; the repetition of statements or phrases in a way reminiscent of a chant
sample_sentences: Much to our delight, the wizard's incantation eventually caused the small stone to turn into a sleek black BMW.

definition: to make very angry
sample_sentences: Jeremy was incensed when i told him that even though he was stupid and loathsome, he would always be my best friend.

definition: unceasing
sample_sentences: I will go deaf and lose my mind if your children don't stop the incessant bickering. A cessation is a ceasing.

definition: beginning; emerging
sample_sentences: Support for the plan was incipient, and the planners hoped it would soon grow and spread.

definition: cutting right to the heart of the matter
sample_sentences: When a surgeon cuts into youo, he or she makes an incision. To be incisive is to be as sharp as a scalpel in a figurative sense.

definition: not harmonious; not consistent; not appropriate; not fitting in
sample_sentences: Bill's membership in the motorcycle gang was incongruous with his mild personality and his career as a management consultant.

definition: incapable of being reformed
sample_sentences: The ever-cheerful Annie is an incorrigible optimist.

definition: an increase; one in a series of increases
sample_sentences: Viola built up her savings account incrementally, one dollar at a time.

definition: not caring one way or the other; apathetic; mediocre
sample_sentences: The painter did an indifferent job, but it was good enough for Suan, who was indifferent about painting.

definition: native; originating in that area
sample_sentences: Fast-food restaurants are indigenous to America, where they were invented.

definition: poor
sample_sentences: The indigent family had little to eat, nothing to spend, and virtually nothing to wear.

definition: angry, especially as a result of something unust or unworthy; insulted.
sample_sentences: Ted became indignant when the policewoman accused him of stealing the nuclear weapon.

definition: lazy
sample_sentences: The indolent teenagers slept late, moped around, and never looked for summer jobs.

definition: incapable of being expressed or described
sample_sentences: The simple beauty of nature is often so ineffable that it brings tears to our eyes

definition: clumsy; incompetent; gauche
sample_sentences: Joshua is an inept dancer; he is as likely to stomp on his partner's foot as he is to step on it.

definition: inactive; sluggish; not reacting chemically
sample_sentences: The baseball team seemed strangely inert; it was as though they had lost the will to play.

definition: relentless; inevitable; unavoidable
sample_sentences: The inexorable waves pounded the shore, as they have always pounded it and as they always will pound it.

definition: shamefully wicked; having an extremely bad reputation; disgraceful
sample_sentences: Deep within the prison was the infamous torture chamber, where hooded guards tickled their prisoners with feathers until they confessed.

definition: foolish; foolishly passionate or attracted; made foolish; foolishy in love
sample_sentences: I was so infatuated with Polly that i drooled and gurgled whenever she was near.

definition: to conclude; to deduce
sample_sentences: Raizel said she loved the bronies, but i inferred from the size of the piece left on her plate that she had actually dispised them.

definition: very, very, very small; infinitely small
sample_sentences: An infinitesimal bug of some kind crawled into Heather's ear and bit her in a place she couldn't scratch

definition: frank; without deception; simple; artless; charmingly naive
sample_sentences: Young children are ingenuous. They don't know much about the ways of the world, and certainly not enough to deceive anyone.

definition: part of the essential nature of something; intrinsic
sample_sentences: There is an inherent strength in steel that cardboard lacks.

definition: a command or order, especially a court order
sample_sentences: Wendy's neighbors got a court injunction prohibiting her from playing her radio.

definition: existing since birth; inborn; inherent
sample_sentences: Joseph's kindness was innate; it was part of his natural character.

definition: harmless; banal
sample_sentences: The speaker's voice was loud but his words were innocuous; there was nothing to get excited about.

definition: excessive; unreasonable
sample_sentences: The math teacher paid an inordinate amount of attention to the grammar rather than algebra.

definition: hard or impossible to satisfy; greedy; avaricious
sample_sentences: Peter's addiction never reached satiety.

definition: treacherous; sneaky
sample_sentences: Winter was insidious; it crept in under the doors and through cracks in the windows.

definition: to hint; to creep in
sample_sentences: When I told her that I hadn't done any laundry in a month, Valerie insinuated that I was a slob.

definition: dull; bland; banal
sample_sentences: Barney's jokes were so insipid that no one in the room managed to force out so much as a chuckle.

definition: arrogant; insulting
sample_sentences: The ill-mannered four-year-old was so insolent that his parents had a hard time finding a babysitter.

definition: to provoke; to stir up
sample_sentences: The strike was instigated by the ambitious uniton president, who wanted to get her name into the news.

definition: like an island; isolated
sample_sentences: The insular little community had very little contact with the world around it.

definition: a rebel; someone who revolts against a government
sample_sentences: The heavily armed insurgents rushed into the persidential palace, but they paused to taste the fresh blueberry pie on the dinner table and were captured by the president's bodyguards.

definition: essential
sample_sentences: A solid offense was an integral part of our football team; so was a strong defense.

definition: to combine two or more things into a whole
sample_sentences: Marisol's school offered an integrated history and language curriculum so that students learned Roman history and Latin in the same classroom.

definition: uncontrollable; stubborn; disobedient
sample_sentences: The intractable child was a torment to his nursery school teacher.

definition: uncompromising; stubborn
sample_sentences: Vijay was an intransigent hard-liner, and he didn't care how many people he offended with his views.

definition: part of the essential nature of something; inherent
sample_sentences: Larry's intrinsic boldness was always getting him into trouble.

definition: tending to think about oneself; examining one's feelings
sample_sentences: The introspective six-year-old never had much to say to other people but always seemed to be turning something over in her mind.

definition: to flood; to cover completely with water; to overwhelm
sample_sentences: The tiny island kingdom was inundated by the tidal wave. Fortunately, no one died from the deluge.

definition: insulting or abusive speech
sample_sentences: The critic's searing review was filled with bitterness and invective.

definition: habitual; firm in habit; deeply rooted
sample_sentences: Erica was such an inverterate liar on the golf course that when she finally made a hole-in-one, she marked it on his score card as a zero.

definition: easily angered or provoked; irritable
sample_sentences: A grouch is irascible. The CEO was so irascible that her employees were afraid to talk to her for fear she might hurl paperweights at them.

definition: meaning the opposite of what you seem to say; using words to mean something other than what they seem to mean
sample_sentences: Eddie was being ironic when he said he loved Peter like a brother; in truth, he hated him

definition: irreversible
sample_sentences: After his friend pointed out that the tattoo was spelled incorrectly, Tom realized that his decision to get a tattoo was irrevocable.

definition: moving from place to place
sample_sentences: The life of a traveling salesman is an itinerant one.

definition: exercising sound judgement
sample_sentences: The firefighters made judicious use of flame-retardant foam on the brush fire before it spread to nearby homes.

definition: to place side by side
sample_sentences: Comedy and tragedy were justaposed in the play, which was alternately funny and sad.

definition: having to do with motion; lively; active
sample_sentences: A kinetic personality is a lively, active, and moving personality.

definition: a maze; something like a maze
sample_sentences: Each of the fifty floors in the office building was a labyrinth of dark corridors and narrow passageways.

definition: using few words, especially to the point of seeming rude
sample_sentences: The manager's laconic dismissal letter left the fired employees feeling angry and hurt.

definition: to mourn
sample_sentences: As the snowstorm gained in intensity, Stan lamented his decision that morning to dress in shorts and a T-shirts.

definition: to satirize; to mock; to parody
sample_sentences: The irreverent students mercilessly lampooned their Latin teacher's lisp in a skit at the school talent show.

definition: to become weak, listless, or depressed
sample_sentences: The formerly eager and vigorous accountant languished in her tedious job at the international conglomerate.

definition: generous giving of gifts (or the gifts themselves); generosity; philanthropy
sample_sentences: Sam was marginally literate at best. Only the largess of his uncle got Sam into the Ivy League school.

definition: present but not visible or apprent; potential
sample_sentences: At four, Maria was a latent shopaholic; she learned to read by browsing the descriptions in clothing catalogs.

definition: to praise; to applaud; to extol; to celebrate
sample_sentences: The bank manager lauded the hero who trapped the escaping robber. The local newspaper published a laudatory editorial on this intrepid individual.

definition: something handed down from the past; a bequest
sample_sentences: A shoebox full of baseball cards was the dead man's only legacy.

definition: sluggishness; laziness; drowsiness; indifference
sample_sentences: After a busy week of sports, homework, and work, the student relished the lethargy of Saturday morning.

definition: lightness; frivolity; unseriousness
sample_sentences: To levitate something is to make it so light that it floats up into the air. Levity comes from the same root and has to do with a different kind of lightness.

definition: a written or published falsehood that injures the reputation of, or defames, someone
sample_sentences: Slander is just like libel except that it is spoken instead of written. To slander someone is to say something untrue that injures that person's reputation.

definition: to try in court; to engage in legal proceedings
sample_sentences: When the company was unable to recover its money outside of court, its only option was to litigate.

definition: talking a lot or too much
sample_sentences: The child was surprisingly loquacious for one so small

definition: clear; easy to understand
sample_sentences: The professor's explanation of the theory of relativity was so astonishingly lucid that even I could understand it.

definition: axaggeratedly mournful
sample_sentences: Harry's lugubrious eulogy at the funeral of his dog eventually made everyone start giggling.

definition: giving off light; glowing; bright
sample_sentences: The moon was a luminous disk in the cloudy nighttime sky.

definition: scheming activity for an evil purpose
sample_sentences: This word is almost always used in the plural - machinations - in which form it means the same thing. The ruthless machinations of the mobsters left a trail of blood and bodies.

definition: forgiving; unresentful; noble in spirit; generous
sample_sentences: The boxer was magnanimous in defeat, telling the sports reporters that his opponent had simply been too talented for him to beat.

definition: a rich, powerful, or very successful businessperson
sample_sentences: John D. Rockerfeller was a manate who was never too cheap to give a shoeshine boy a dime for his troubles.

definition: a feeling of depression, uneasiness, or queasiness
sample_sentences: Malaise descended on the calculus class when the teacher announced a quiz.

definition: an illegal act, especially by a public official
sample_sentences: President Ford officially pardoned former president Nixon before the latter could be convicted of any malfeasance.

definition: to pretend to be sick to avoid doing work
sample_sentences: Indolent Leon always malingered when it was his turn to clean up the house.

definition: easy to shape or bend
sample_sentences: Modeling clay is very malleable. So is Stuart. We can make him do whatever we want him to do.

definition: a command or authorization to do something; the will of the voters as expressed by the results of an election
sample_sentences: Our mandate from the executive committee was to find the answer to the problem as quickly as possible.

definition: visible; evident
sample_sentences: There is manifest danger in riding a pogo stick along the edge of a cliff. Manifest can also be a verb, in which case it means to show, to make visible, or to make evident.

definition: a public declaration of beliefs or principles, usually political ones
sample_sentences: The Communist Manifesto was a document that spelled out Karl Marx's critique of capitalistic society.

definition: to arrange in order; to gather together for the purpose of doing something
sample_sentences: The statistician marshaled her facts numerous times before making her presentation.

definition: warlike; having to do with combat
sample_sentences: The parade of soldiers was martial in tone; the soldiers carried riffles and were followed by a formation of tanks.

definition: someone who gives up his or her life in pursuit of a cause, especially a religious one; one who suffers from a cause; one who makes a show of suffering in order to arouse sympathy.
sample_sentences: Many of the saints were also martyrs; they were executed, often gruesomely, for refusing to renounce their religious beliefs.

definition: to enroll, especially at a college
sample_sentences: Benny told everyone he was going to Harvard, but he actually matriculated to the local junior college.

definition: silly and overly sentimental
sample_sentences: The high school reunion grew more and more maudlin as the participants shared more and more memories.

definition: a nonconformist; a rebel
sample_sentences: The word maverick originated in the Old West. It is derived from the name of Samuel A. Maverick, a Texas banker who once accepted a herd of cattle in payment of a debt. Maverick was a banker, not a rancher. He failed to confine or brand his calves, which habitually wandered into his neighbor's pastures. Local ranchers got in the habit of referring to any unbranded calf as a maverick. The word is now used for anyone who has refused to be "branded" - who has refused to conform.

definition: fundamental principle; an old saying
sample_sentences: We always tried to live our lives according to the maxim that it is better to give than to receive.

definition: to help settle differences
sample_sentences: The United Nations representative tried to mediate between the warring countries, but the soldiers just kept shooting at one another.

definition: sweetly flowing
sample_sentences: Mellifluous comes from Greek words meaning, roughly, "honey flowing." We use the word almost exclusively to describe voices, music, or sounds that flow sweetly, like honey.

definition: lying; dishonest
sample_sentences: Thieves are naturally mendacious. If you ask them what they are doing, they will automatically answer, "Nothing".

definition: a beggar
sample_sentences: The presence of thousands of mendicants in every urban area is a sad commentary on our national priorities.

definition: a teacher, tutor, counselor, or coach; especially in business, an experienced person who shows an inexperienced person the ropes
sample_sentences: Mentor is too big a word to apply to just any teacher. A student might have many teachers but only one mentor - the person who taught him or her what was really important.

definition: a hired soldier; someone who will do anything for money
sample_sentences: Mercenary can also be used as an adjective. Larry's motives in writing the screenplay for the trashy movie were strictly mercenary - he needed the money.

definition: emotionally unpredictable; repidly changing in mood
sample_sentences: A person with a mercurial personality is one who changes rapidly and unpredictably between one mood and another.

definition: a magical change in form; a striking or sudden change
sample_sentences: When the magician passed her wand over Eileen's head, she underwent a bizarre metamorphosis: she turned into a hamster.

definition: the world in miniature
sample_sentences: The cosmos is the heavens, cosmopolitan means wordly, and a microcosm is a miniature version of the world. all three words are related.

definition: environment; surroundings
sample_sentences: A caring and involved community is the proper milieu for raising a family.

definition: very tiny
sample_sentences: Be careful with the spelling of this word. People tend to spell it "miniscule." Think of minus. Minute (mye NOOT) is a synonym for minuscule. The small details of something are the minutiae (mi NOO shi ee).

definition: hating mankind
sample_sentences: A misogynist (mis AH juh nist) hates women. A misanthropic person doens't make distinctions; he or she hates everyone. The opposite of a misanthrope (MIS un throhp) is a philanthropist (fuh LAN thruhpist). Curiously, there is no word for someone who hates men only.

definition: to moderate the effect of something
sample_sentences: The sense of imminent disaster was mitigated by the guide's calm behavior and easy smile.

definition: to soften; to soothe; to pacify
sample_sentences: Lucy mollified the angry police officer by kissing his hand.

definition: massive, solid, uniform, and unyielding
sample_sentences: A monolith is a huge stone shaft or column. Many other things can be said to be monolithic. A huge corporation is often said to be monolithic, especially if it is enormous and powerful and all its parts are dedicated to the same purpose.

definition: dying
sample_sentences: The steel industry in this country was moribund a few years ago, but now it seems to be reviving somewhat.

definition: gloomy; sullen
sample_sentences: Louise was always so morose about everything that she was never any fun to be with.

definition: to humiliate
sample_sentences: I was mortified when my father asked my girlfriend whether she thought I was a dumb, pathetic wimp.

definition: ordinary; pretty boring; not heavenly and eternal
sample_sentences: My day was filled with mundane chores: I mowed the lawn, did the laundry, and fed the dog.

definition: very generous; lavish
sample_sentences: The munificent millionaire gave lots of money to any charity that came to her with a request.

definition: nearsightedness; lack of foresight
sample_sentences: Myopia is the fancy medical name for the inability to see clearly at a distance. It's also a word used in connection with people who lack other kinds of visual acuity. The president suffered from economic myopia; he was unable to see the consequences of his fiscal policies.
